3category: # NOTE: Iberian is UNDECIPHERED. Meanings are PROPOSED by scholars based on
# context, find-spots (sanctuaries, necropoleis), associated objects, and
# comparison with neighboring cultures. All interpretations are tentative.

scholarly_basis: Widely accepted as theonym; appears on sanctuary lead tablets, often with iunstir; cf. Untermann 1990, Velaza 2015
Extremely common in personal names and toponyms; may be theophoric (cf. Basque ili "city"?) or divine element; debated
Appears in onomastic compounds; possibly related to Celtic Belenos or independent theonym
Very common name element; cf. Latin "atta" (father); possibly theophoric
Core votive term; appears on sanctuary objects and lead tablets; often paired with neitin; variants: iunstiŕ, iumstiŕ, iunsti-
Widely accepted as verb of making/dedicating; appears in ownership and votive contexts across many sites
Extremely common at end of inscriptions; proposed as "I" (1st person) or possessive marker in votive formulas
Proposed as verbal form meaning "to give/offer"; appears in contexts suggesting dedication
Consistently appears in funerary/memorial contexts; proposed as "tomb" or "grave monument"
Appears in long votive texts alongside neitin and iunstir; possibly a ritual term
Often appears with numerals; proposed as unit of value or "silver"; possibly offering-payment
Appears with Roman numerals; possibly counting dedicated objects
Extremely common; proposed as article, determinative, or "son" (patronymic)
Common in personal name compounds; possibly a title or name element
Appears in votive contexts, possibly a ritual role or title
May designate a role; appears in long sanctuary texts
Common in names; possibly containing divine element
Appears in sanctuary contexts; possibly related to sacredness
Appears in votive texts; possibly a place designation or sanctuary term
Common element in personal names found at sanctuary sites

3category: # IV. INSCRIPTIONS FROM KNOWN SANCTUARY SITES

scholarly_basis: neitiniunstir anbaikabalika ilbikon... — sanctuary lead tablet
neitin:basetiŕa:iuns tir:baŕbinkite... — with counting marks
uśtalar:ortinbeŕeteŕeikiaŕ śalir o III: neitiniunstir — votive
iltiŕbikis: en:seltar: ḿi — funerary/votive formula
iunstir:beleśaiŕ...iunstir:ekiartone:beleśtar... — major votive
Contains: iunstirlakú, bototaś, uśtalarilune, banḿiŕeśu — major ritual inscription
iunstir:śalirg:basiŕtiŕ:sabaŕi dai... — offering with counting
Contains iunstir 4+ times — repetitive votive/ritual formula
ekiar:saltutibaite:iumstiŕ — dedication formula
seltarbanḿi...kaŕieukiarseltarbanḿi — double funerary formula
aŕe:take aiunibaiseate teban:a — possible offering text
...neitin... — northern attestation of deity name
sakaŕbeś...ebanalbasusbeliginela — southern ritual text
neitinke subake:e:i:tako — with suffix -ke (possibly ablative)
Parallels Latin "X fecit"; ownership/dedication

proposed_meaning: (this is) the tomb of X, mine
scholarly_basis: Funerary dedication formula
Deity invocation + offering term
Verbal phrase of dedication
Quantified offerings or payments
Two-verb votive formula (V.04.01)
Always co-occur in CS.21 sanctuary texts
Prefixes may designate different offering types

3category: # ADDITIONS FROM RECHECK (comprehensive sweep for missing terms)

scholarly_basis: Appears in bilingual T.11.05 alongside Latin FVLVIA LINTEARIA; paired with teban
Appears in AUD.05 Ensérune sanctuary area
Paired with aŕe:take in same inscription
Adjacent to broken "iusti---tir" (=iunstir)
Exclusive to CS.21 sanctuary; always with iunstir and bototaś
Opens CS.21.05 text as "iŕe:bototaś"; inflected forms: bototaśeai, bototaśeiké, bototaśté; exclusive to CS.21
Appears between neitin (deity) and iunstir in "neitin:basetiŕa:iunstir"; possibly divine epithet
Flanked by two iunstir; the -lir ending shared with śalir and buranalir may indicate ritual noun class
Doubled in text: "borsté:abaŕkeborsté"; co-occurs with saltukó and neitékeŕu
Two variants in same text; co-occurs with borsté and neitékeŕu (deity variant?)
Opens the longest votive text CS.21.05 as "iŕe:bototaś"; may function as ritual opener
kúleśbuŕka, "alaśbuŕ:śal" — sacred site place-names in Ensérune sanctuary texts
Widespread; appears in GI.15 sanctuary, CS.21 votive, and T.11 bilingual text
Second element in compound names: akaś-tikeŕ, iltir-tikeŕ
Very common; also as final element: iltiŕ-baś, biuŕti-baś
Appears in A.04.01b alongside iunstir and śalir
First element of compounds: neŕse-oŕtin, neŕse-atin; CS.16 near sanctuary zone
In compounds: biuŕ-táneś, iltiŕ-táneś, atin-táneś; appears at sanctuary sites with counting marks
Systematically paired with śalir and karte; V.07.01 has tallies up to 20 strokes
Different prefixes may designate different offering types or denominations
Marks formal structure in ritual texts; two vacats in CS.18.01 votive text
Major ritual text with unique terms; doubled borsté; neitékeŕu may be variant of neitin
Continuation of CS.21.05 ritual; repeats uskéiké-iunstir formula
Contains 5+ uskéiké-iunstir pairs; longest sustained ritual formula
śiśalirbitíŕokánkube — combined śalir and biteŕokan; "itiatu:ban:kutur:biteŕokan"
